column2: also called York Region
column3: is a regional municipality in Southern Ontario
column4: Canada
column5: between Lake Simcoe and Toronto. It replaced the former York County in 1971
column6: and is part of the Greater Toronto Area and the inner ring of the Golden Horseshoe. The regional government is headquartered in Newmarket.

column4: with a growth rate of 7.5% from 2011 to 2016. The Government of Ontario expects its population to surpass 1.5 million residents by 2031.

column1: At a meeting in Richmond Hill on May 6
column3: officials representing the municipalities of York County approved plans for the creation of a regional government entity to replace York County. The plan had been presented in 1969 by Darcy McKeough
column4: the Ontario Minister of Municipal Affairs
column5: taking about a year to determine municipal boundaries within the new regional government.The Regional Municipality of York was created by Act of the Legislative Assembly of Ontario in 1970
column7: 1971. The creation of the regional municipality resulted in the consolidation of the fourteen former municipalities of York County into nine new municipalities:

column1: The township of Whitchurch merged with the town of Stouffville to create the town of Whitchurch–Stouffville
column2: ceding land to Aurora
column3: Newmarket
column4: and Richmond Hill to the west of the proposed Highway 404 and annexing a northern strip of land from the township of Markham. The western boundary of the new town of Markham was defined to be at Yonge Street
column5: where its northern boundary was formed with Richmond Hill (to which it ceded land) and its western boundary with the new town Vaughan. The new town of Vaughan would consist of all communities in the area bounded by Markham and Richmond Hill in the east
column7: the periphery of the regional municipality in the west
column8: and the new township of King in the north.The townships of Georgina
column10: and Sutton were merged into the township of Georgina
column11: and the East Gwillimbury neighbourhood of East Gwillimbury Heights was merged into Newmarket. King formed the northwestern part of the new region
column12: but the eastern lot from Bathurst Street to Yonge Street was ceded to Newmarket
column15: the last of which became a part of Richmond Hill. The boundary between Aurora and Newmarket was defined to be St. John's Sideroad
column16: and Newmarket's northern boundary was defined to be Green Lane.The towns of Aurora
column18: and Richmond Hill were defined to be the growth centres for the regional municipality
column19: which was to become a greenbelt between the denser urban areas of Toronto to the south and Barrie to the north. The growth centres were each restricted to grow to a maximum population of 25
column22: 000.The municipal realignment merged 40% of East Gwillimbury's population into Newmarket. The council of East Gwillimbury voted to amalgamate with Newmarket
column23: but Newmarket council opposed the amalgamation. In the plan presented by McKeough
column24: the councils of the towns of Newmarket and Aurora were given ten years to decide whether or not to amalgamate.The internal municipal realignments resulted in some politicians residing in a new municipality from that which they represented at the time of realignment. The reeve of Whitchurch Township resided in the western portion of the town that was annexed by Aurora

column1: Because of the mix of urban and rural areas in the Region
column2: the provision of electricity was governed in a different manner from the rest of the regional services:

column1: the hydro-electric commissions and public utilities commissions that existed at the end of 1970 continued to provide electricity within their respective areas;
the councillors of the former Township of Vaughan and the trustees of the former Police Village of King City became members of new Hydro-Electric Commissions for their respective areas;

Ontario Hydro continued to have responsibility for providing electricity to those portions of the Region that were not served by any of the above commissions.Electric distribution was partially rationalized in 1978
column2: when:

column1: hydro-electric commissions were established for all area municipalities except East Gwillimbury (but it could establish a commission later on
column2: subject to Ontario Hydro's consent);

column3: all assets of the former commissions in the Region were transferred to the new commissions;

column1: Ontario Hydro withdrew its provision of services from all areas except those in East Gwillimbury
column2: Georgina
column3: King and Whitchurch-Stouffville;

column2: King and Whitchurch-Stouffville could take over responsibility for such areas at a later date

column2: ample snowfall
column3: more in the northern part of York region much of it derived from the wind driven snowbelt streamer activity.

column1: The economy of York Region is diverse. In general
column2: the economy includes a full range of businesses from industrial to high-tech to rural/agricultural. New developments continually consume space year after year
column3: and tend to be focused along the Yonge Street corridor from Vaughan/Richmond Hill in the south to Newmarket/Aurora in the north. There are ongoing conflicts between conservationists and developers over land use. Most contentious is the conflict use of the Oak Ridges Moraine.

column1: The arterial road network in York Region is a grid
column2: with most roads running north–south or east–west. This was done under the orders of British surveyor Augustus Jones during the 1790s. York Region assigned approximately 50 roads as York Regional Routes
column3: meaning that the cost of maintaining of these roads is paid for by York Region.

column1: Water in southern York is provided by Toronto Water and Peel Region by way of 3 pumping stations and reservoirs (Bayview
column2: Dufferin and Milliken (tank and underground reservoir)) using water from Lake Ontario. Keswick and Sutton obtain water from Lake Simcoe by way of water treatment plants. The remainder of York obtains water from a combination of water from Lake Ontario and underground wells. Some wells are maintained by the Region and the rest privately.

column11: the latter operating English first language separate schools.
